content:
I started working on an RFC defining the types team:

https://hackmd.io/kREtk8pdTfC5lz97jGYjFA

Very early and incomplete draft, planning to steal material from the other writeup.
(deleted)

One thing I am thinking about is that we will need some protocol for compiler team to "nominate" issues to our attention. I don't particularly want to do triage meetings, I'm hoping we can avoid that, but perhaps a specific Zulip stream (#t-types/nominations) or something would suffice.
(cc @pnkfelix and @Wesley Wiser on that)
I think in some form or another, we will have to do some kind of triage
For example, there are many "types related" P-high issues open
I could imagine that being an initiative to drive those down
And at some point, we do need to go through these
the scenario I am thinking is:
"new soundness issue occurs, someone needs to respond to it"
I don't think we necessarily need regular triage issues though

Jack Huey said:

And at some point, we do need to go through these

@oli has been doing some of that, actually
I do want us to get to "inbox zero"
Agreed
Here is an (incomplete) list of issues probably under types team: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues?q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+label%3AWG-traits
Some are tracking issues, other soundness bugs, etc.

Current membership:

  • oli-obk
  • spastorino
  • compiler-errors
  • lcnr
  • matthewjasper
  • lqd
am I overlooking folks? no doubt I am
I guess there are a variety of compiler folks who might or might not want to be involved :)
could probably leave this out of the RFC
I think current membership is best left out of RFC
agreed

Leads and membership

The current team leads are Nicholas Matsakis (nikomatsakis) and Jack Huey. Initial membership will be determined by the leads after team is created.
that's what I wrote
Works for me

Leads

Leads are responsible for:

  • Leading and scheduling team meetings
  • Selecting the deep dive meetings
  • Making decisions regarding team membership
  • General "buck stops here"-type decisions

Leads typically serve for 6 months to 1 year, at which point we will consider whether to rotate.

Team membership

Membership in the team is awarded on the basis of experience working on the implementation, source, or design of an active initiative. Membership is kept up to date; if you are inactive for >6 months, we may move you to the alumni team.

To become a member you typically have to (a) contribute consistently over a period of multiple months and (b) lead at least one "deep dive" (see below). The second point may be waived.

This section contains "current details" about what the team is up to. These details are expected to change over time.
I also wrote that general material
well, copy-and-pasted
OK, first draft of RFC is basically done from my pov
link

Drawbacks:
Complicates "ownership" of things a bit. It's harder to tell what's lang vs types or compiler vs types. (Imagine a big PR that touches a lot of rustc code, including trait solving, does that change need to be signed off by types team? Or compiler team?)
What about repo access? Not everyone on the membership list has r+ privileges for rustc right now.

Prior art: Maybe other forms of organization in the rust project? Teams, initiatives, working groups, projects. (For teams, specifically T-rustdoc is one that I think is good to draw parallels to in terms of repo access and such)
Future possibilites: Other subteams?
@nikomatsakis I added my nits to the RFC draft you made
This it's ready to be opened today?
